slides.title: Brief
slides.text:
Create a blogging platform with the following features:

  • Users can create and edit their unique accounts
  • A home-page with a list of articles that are available for everyone to view
  • Logged in users can write, edit and delete their own articles
  • Logged in users can also view and write comments, delete their own comments, and moderate others' comments on their own articles
  • All articles and user information is stored in a database, with no passwords saved as plaintext
  • An extra feature of our team's choosing - we chose to implement a toggleable article profanity filter

slides.title: Design
slides.text:
We started by outlining the tables, their columns and relationships between them for the SQL database.

Following the database design, we mocked up the layout of the website.

Once we iterated through several mockups, we created a list of the required features as user stories on a kanban board for project management.

slides.title: Build
slides.text:
The project was managed in a GitLab repository with a ‘Feature Branching’ workflow.

We individually worked on features on our own branches and when completed would submit a pull request to be peer reviewed and merged to master once passed.

This worked extremely well as conflicts were regularly identified and resolved, and all team members had up-to-date versions of the project.

slides.title: Deployment
slides.text:
The original version of this project wasn't deployed, but I took it upon myself to do so.
The first step was hosting the SQL database in Google Cloud via Cockroachlabs.cloud. To do this I had to reformat the database as PostgreSQL from SQLite.

The frontend was then hosted in a Google Cloud Function via Firebase.

slides.title: Deployment
slides.text:
Deployed via a Firebase CI/CD pipeline utilising a GitHub build action.
This means that as soon as a pull request is merged, the updated master branch is immediately deployed to production in Firebase without having to manually call npm run build and Firebase deploy.
